title: Public Roadmap

last_post.content:
Some cool things on the roadmap for future versions of #Mastodon...

Most looking forward to these:

➡️ Groups
➡️ Markdown formatting for posts
➡️ Additional Search Syntax
➡️ Hide User on List from Main Feed
➡️ Letting you add pending follows to Lists
➡️ Add the ability to import lists

And in explore:

➡️ Login with Passkeys
➡️ Quote Posts
➡️ Thread Pagination
➡️ Home feed digest
➡️ On-hover information cards for users
➡️ End-to-end encrypted messages

https://joinmastodon.org/roadmap

title: Putin's Twitter account resurfaces as Russia comes in from the cold

last_post.content:
Over on the bad site, Twitter has lifted restrictions on Kremlin accounts and is no longer limiting the reach of Kremlin media accounts.

Russian government tweets are appearing in Twitter’s algorithmically-driven “For You” feed for newly created accounts, even when they did not follow them. So Twitter is not just *showing* these Kremlin accounts — it's algorithmically *boosting* them.

https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2023/04/07/elon-musk-twitter-lifts-restrictions-putin-kremlin-russia/

title: ChatGPT’s inconsistent moral advice influences users’ judgment - Scientific Reports

last_post.content:
My first thought: We need a paper about what ChatGPT does with the trolley problem like a hole in the head.

My second thought—and don't confuse this for an endorsement of the paper—was much darker: we probably DO need work on this, and on how humans are influenced by it. The latter is the primary of the subject of the paper.

I was going to complain about how I think the authors rather naively talk about an LLM's moral stance as if such a thing could exist, but...

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-023-31341-0

The media, at least those that are even bothering to cover it, are truly missing the forest for the trees. title: Six Centuries of Type & Printing (letterpress and ebook bundle)

last_post.content: Back in 2020, I published Six Centuries of Type & Printing, a concise book – 64 pages – that actually starts centuries before Gutenberg, with Chinese and Korea printing, and then digs into 1450 to 2020, covering ~600 years of technological advances. Set in hot-metal type (Monotype Bembo) in North Yorkshire, printed in London, and bound in Germany with a foil-stamped cover & slipcase, I still have copies available for shipping worldwide! https://glog.glennf.com/tiny-type-museum-time-capsule-and-more/six-centuries-letterpress (ebook edition available)

title: Burj Al Babas: Inside an Abandoned Town of Disney-esque Castles

last_post.content: ❝ With many of the villas started but not one finished, the town remains unlivable. From afar, the gray-roofed neighborhood looks like something out of a Disney movie but, upon closer inspection, Burj Al Babas boasts an eerie postapocalyptic feel with rows of partially completed castles, patchy landscaping, and zero signs of life. The empty village is chilling, to say the least—like a sparkling city ravaged by war. ❞ → https://www.architecturaldigest.com/gallery/burj-al-babas

title: FSW 2023 : Day 3 - Remote Work: the Good, the Bad, the Ugly, and the Way Forward

last_post.content:
What happened to the future of work? My keynote about REMOTE WORK from 2 weeks ago. TL;DR:
1. After 40 years of research into what makes remote work succeed …
2. … the pandemic era was a parade of catastrophic “worst hits”!
3. But our workplaces are broken, so workers don’t want to go “back”
4. Fixing these problems can help us move forward to a better “future of work”

title: https://neurodifferent.me

last_post.content:
To my fellow disconnected members of neurodifferent.me, while I hope this issue gets resolved soon, I'd probably recommend exporting your current data just in case. This is so you can import some of your data into a different Mastodon instance/server.

To get the backup, you need to log into your account via the website, I don't think apps will work.

1: Sign in to https://neurodifferent.me
2: Go to https://neurodifferent.me/settings/export
3: At the bottom of that page, there should be an option to get an archive. It may take a few minutes, you should get an email when it's ready.
4: When ready, download the file to a safe place in case you need it in the future.

You can only do this once every seven days, so if you've done it in the past week, you'll probably be unable to export until enough time passes.

title: GitHub - grantmcdermott/plot2: Lightweight extension of base R's plot function

last_post.content:
We all love ggplot2 (obvs), but base R plot is underrated IMO.

I finally packaged up a script I've had lying around for a while. The `plot2` #rstats 📦 is a lightweight extension to base R plot that automates grouped plotting and legend handling (plus some extras). https://github.com/grantmcdermott/plot2

title: United States v. American Tel. and Tel. Co., 552 F. Supp. 131 (D.D.C. 1983)

last_post.content:
While we're talking telephones, I recently re-read the 1982 "Modification of Final Judgement" that broke up the Bell System into separate local and long distance companies, changing the landscape of US telecom forever.

Aside from the huge impact of the case itself, the opinion is a fascinating history, especially for the significant role Bell Labs played in shaping Judge Greene's rulings.

Long, but richly repays a careful reading. https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/FSupp/552/131/1525975/

title: The Short Life and Humiliating Death of the Clipper Chip

last_post.content:
This month is the 30th anniversary of the announcement of the Clipper Chip, the first of many bad ideas for weakening cryptography with "key escrow" backdoors. Clipper is long dead, but its ghost continues to haunt us from time to time.

https://gizmodo.com/life-and-death-of-clipper-chip-encryption-backdoors-att-1850177832

title: https://lnkd.in/e-D7uJpF

last_post.content:
If anyone has a secret mobile phone hidden from an abusive partner, remember to switch off or put in airplane mode etc as described below, or the phone will be activated with the loud alert on the evening of 23/04.

Please share this to help keep others safe

The alert will say:

“This is a test of Emergency Alerts, a new UK government service that will warn you if there’s a life-threatening emergency nearby.

In an actual emergency, follow the instructions in the alert to keep yourself and others safe.

Visit gov.uk/alerts for more information.

This is a test. You do not need to take any action.”

Mobile phone masts in the surrounding area will broadcast an alert. Every compatible mobile phone or tablet in range of a mast will receive the alert.

Your mobile phone or tablet does not have to be connected to mobile data or wifi to get alerts.

You can opt out of emergency alerts, but the government advises you should keep them switched on for your own safety.

To opt out:

Search your settings for ‘emergency alerts’.
Turn off ‘severe alerts’ and ‘extreme alerts’.
If you still get alerts, contact your device manufacturer for help.

Refuge have produced a really helpful video @ https://lnkd.in/e-D7uJpF

#domesticabuse #domesticviolence #safeguarding #safeguardingchildren #safetyplan #emergencyservices

title: Oquonie by Rek & Devine

last_post.content:
You know what? I think Oquonie is complete.

For the past two months @rek and I ported a game of ours for its 10th years anniversary since iOS updates broke it beyond repair.

It has been rewritten to target a virtual machine, which should(hopefully) help us keeping it playable. In the next few days I'll release a document that explains how to write an emulator to run the game.

get game: https://hundredrabbits.itch.io/oquonie
get emulator: https://100r.co/site/uxn.html
get source: https://git.sr.ht/~rabbits/oquonie

#finishit

- the keycaps feel very Siemensy
- they layout feels pretty distinctive

title: Implementation Science Seeks to Translate Research Into Practice

last_post.content:
Implementation science is one of the core things I do, but surprisingly few people know this important set of skills, interdisciplinary fields, and communities exists, working to translate evidence into action. At Google as a metrics and evaluation scientist, at Khan Academy as an efficacy scientist, and of course as the founder of an evidence science consultancy, all my applied research work has included implementation science.

https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2803716

title: $388 in Sushi. Just a $20 Tip: The Brutal Math of Uber Eats and DoorDash

last_post.content: It’s time to get rid of tipping. In North America, service employers deliberately underpay servers and delivery people hoping we’ll make up the difference. But these employers often skim off these tips as well. Tips used to be about service, but now it’s just sanctioned wage theft. Employers should be forced to pay people what their labour is worth. https://www.nytimes.com/2023/04/09/business/uber-eats-door-dash-delivery-tips.html?smid=nytcore-ios-share&referringSource=articleShare

title: Mary W. Jackson Biography

last_post.content:
Mathematician and aerospace engineer Mary Jackson was born #OTD in 1921. She worked at the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics until it was succeeded by NASA in 1958. Jackson then became the first Black woman to work as a NASA engineer.

Bio: https://www.nasa.gov/content/mary-w-jackson-biography
Image: NASA

ProPublica did it right. The Post did it wrong.
